results.title: The Legendary Rex
results.creator_credit: Jason White, Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The Rex Theatre, in Charlton, was built in 1938 and opened with the film ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’. David Pollard, who worked as a projectionist at the theatre since 1980, takes us on a tour of this historic theatre. He is the Chairperson of the Charlton Community Theatre and has been working towards getting The Rex into community ownership, as there is not a large population base for the theatre to be commercially viable.
The community has offered voluntary labour and raised over $80,000 and with the help of fundraising from the federal government, it is hoped the theatre will eventually be completely in the hands of the community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jason White, Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: Victimised, Assimalised, Correctionalised
results.creator_credit: Howard Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a child, Howard Edwards was shunted from orphanage to orphanage. Made a ward of the state in 1956, he was abused and beaten wherever he was sent. His incarceration didn’t end there and for much of his adult life Howard was a target for police and he was often locked up at the slightest provocation. A large part of Howard’s journey towards healing involved reconnecting with his family, his work in the community and on the board of the Aboriginal Health Care Service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Howard Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: May Johnson
results.brief_description: Leonie Alexander tells the story of her mother May Johnson, an elder of the Barkandji tribe. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Koorie Heritage Trust.

results.title: What's the name of that place you come from nan?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Rita Hinekauia Morrison
results.brief_description: Rita comes from a mixed cultural background but her strongest connection is with the Maori side of her family. She shares her memories and family history in this digital story so that her Maori heritage can be preserved through future generations.

results.title: It's all been great!
results.brief_description:
Wayne is not only a playing member of the local BBC Bowling Club but he also plays tennis and captains a basketball team. Here he speaks of his various achievements, his love of sport and particularly his love for his family.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: Hoarse
results.brief_description:
Clever use of claymation brings to life this amazingly frenetic and captivating tale of one bro’s horse-riding adventures as he regales with enthusiasm about his “bestest” horse and his “bestest” accident.
Contains frequent use of coarse language.

results.title: Something You Call Unique: A Portrait of Homelessness
results.brief_description: This video program focuses on one of Australia’s largest youth welfare agencies - the Salvation Army’s Crossroads Youth Project. The program examines various issues in the debate about welfare and social justice. This examination is based on the people who are directly involved and various points of view are put forth. Central to the program is the reality of day to day functioning of the Centre as it works with the alienation and frustration of the young people who seek support there. The presentation is frank, and will promote lively discussion on the issues of welfare and homelessness.
